linkTarget.anchoringText: The log data show the presence of oil below the transition zone, with high oil saturation below the Free Water Level (Fig. 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Water saturation logs, DST located at the base of the main oil column and core retort data demonstrating the presence of oil below the Free Water Level.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water saturation logs, DST located at the base of the main oil column and core retort data demonstrating the presence of oil below the Free Water Level.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The plot of the core plug retort measurements data versus depth (ft TVDss) shows a clear presence of oil below the Free Water Level (Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Plot of the water saturation versus depth of all the wells, illustrating the vertical distribution of the fluids in the studied field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Plot of the water saturation versus depth of all the wells, illustrating the vertical distribution of the fluids in the studied field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the literature and from observations made in other fields in the Middle East (Arab, 1990, Al-Ajmi et al, 2001, Carpentier et al, 1998, Carpentier et al, 2006, Jedaan et al, 2007, Heydari 2010), the residual oil is explained by the presence of a paleo oil-water contact. An early water movement and sweep of the accumulated oil, induced by tectonic events after its charging, has induced the trapping of residual oil below the curent Free Water Level. This theory is also supported by the presence of tarmat above and below this Free Water Level along a paleo oil-water contact (Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Occurrence of tarmat (reservoir bitumen) above and below the current FWL along a paleo-oil/water contact in several wells located in different parts of the studied field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Occurrence of tarmat (reservoir bitumen) above and below the current FWL along a paleo-oil/water contact in several wells located in different parts of the studied field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The analysis of water saturation logs for all wells enabled the definition of two types of wells. Wells showing the presence of residual oil below the Free Water Level and wells with clean transition zone without any residual oil below the Free Water Level (Fig. 4). The spatial position of these wells allowed the definition of two different areas (Fig. 5):

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Water saturation logs showing the vertical and lateral distribution of the fluids in the studied field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water saturation logs showing the vertical and lateral distribution of the fluids in the studied field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The analysis of water saturation logs for all wells enabled the definition of two types of wells. Wells showing the presence of residual oil below the Free Water Level and wells with clean transition zone without any residual oil below the Free Water Level (Fig. 4). The spatial position of these wells allowed the definition of two different areas (Fig. 5):

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: The analysis of water saturation logs for all wells recognizes two types of wells, wells with residual oil below the FWL and wells with clean transition zone without any residual oil. The spatial position of these wells delineates two areas with same fluid distribution, inner and outer ring areas.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The analysis of water saturation logs for all wells recognizes two types of wells, wells with residual oil below the FWL and wells with clean transition zone without any residual oil. The spatial position of these wells delineates two areas with same fluid distribution, inner and outer ring areas.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, the surface built from the base of the zone showing residual oil in the outer ring and tarmat above the Free Water Level in the inner ring will correspond to the paleo oil-water contact across the whole field. This surface shows a similar geometry as the top of the reservoir of the studied field "anticline", but with lower amplitude (Fig. 6). This geometry is the result of a late tectonic event leading to the compression of the studied field's structure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: The geometry of the surface "base of the zone with residual oil" built from the "deepest point showing residual oil" appears to be of a curved shape "anticline" with a similar geometry as the top of the reservoir of the studied field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The geometry of the surface "base of the zone with residual oil" built from the "deepest point showing residual oil" appears to be of a curved shape "anticline" with a similar geometry as the top of the reservoir of the studied field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The inner ring is more characterized by drainage effects as the oil is moving into the water zone. In this area a clean transition zone can be identified without any residual oil below it (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: 3D distribution of the fluid vs 3D geometry of the studied field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D distribution of the fluid vs 3D geometry of the studied field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results of the methodology described above show a very good match above the Free Water Level; however the method is unable to capture the oil below it (Fig. 8). Therefore a dedicated workflow has been generated to capture this oil and this later is described in the next paragraph.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: The application of the Cuddy method (multi-variable linear regression) for water saturation modeling is achieving a very good match above the Free Water Level. However it is unable to capture the oil below it (SW-1). The use of a dedicated workflow allows a better match of the water saturation above and below the Free Water Level (Final SW).

formatted-caption.caption-text: The application of the Cuddy method (multi-variable linear regression) for water saturation modeling is achieving a very good match above the Free Water Level. However it is unable to capture the oil below it (SW-1). The use of a dedicated workflow allows a better match of the water saturation above and below the Free Water Level (Final SW).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The grid obtained from the previous step below the Free Water Level was then merged with the main grid generated using the saturation height functions. The resulting product is the water saturation grid which captures the transition zone and the residual oil above the paleo-oil/water contact (Fig. 8 and 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Plots of the water saturation versus depth (TVDss) for both model and logs showing the quality of the match of the water saturation above the Free Water Level and the residual oil above the paleo-oil water contact.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Plots of the water saturation versus depth (TVDss) for both model and logs showing the quality of the match of the water saturation above the Free Water Level and the residual oil above the paleo-oil water contact.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Quantitative quality control: by checking the hydrocarbon pore height along the wells (drilled during the early field life) for both saturation grid and logs (Fig. 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Plot of hydrocarbon pore height (HCPV) along the well (drilled during the early field life) for both water saturation grid and logs showing the quality of the match.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Plot of hydrocarbon pore height (HCPV) along the well (drilled during the early field life) for both water saturation grid and logs showing the quality of the match.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Injector WI is a perfect example of this issue (Fig. 11). This well exhibits a consistent injection history with no communication problem with other reservoirs. However, the gap between the simulated Bottom Hole Closed In Pressure (BHCIP) and the historic data is as high as 500psi, eventhough the permeability grid around the well is honouring the available pressure fall-off data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Plot of pressure vs time of the well WI showing a systematic high shut-in pressures compared to the simulation results.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Plot of pressure vs time of the well WI showing a systematic high shut-in pressures compared to the simulation results.

linkTarget.anchoringText: These high pressures can only be explained by the presence of residual oil below the Free Water Level, which acts as a baffle inducing a partial confinement of the injectors. The baffle effects are explained by the effect of the relative permeabilities (ratio of effective permeability of a particular fluid at a particular saturation to absolute permeability). Each of the 3 zones of the outer ring described previously is characterized by a certain range of water saturation implying a different behavior in terms of relative permeabilities (Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: The high pressures are explained by the presence of residual oil below the Free Water Level, which acts as a baffle inducing a partial confinement of the injectors. The baffle effects are explained by the effect of the relative permeabilities.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The high pressures are explained by the presence of residual oil below the Free Water Level, which acts as a baffle inducing a partial confinement of the injectors. The baffle effects are explained by the effect of the relative permeabilities.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Each of the 3 zones of the outer ring described previously is characterized by a certain range of water saturation implying a different behavior in terms of relative permeabilities (Fig. 12). The presence of the residual oil reduces the injected water mobility and leads to an increase of the pressure at the injectors. This phenomenon is more pronounced in the upper part of the reservoir in the studied field as it is the most affected by the presence of residual oil (Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Map and cross section showing the results of the implementation of the residual oil in the simulation model and its impact on the water mobility.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map and cross section showing the results of the implementation of the residual oil in the simulation model and its impact on the water mobility.

linkTarget.anchoringText: By implementing the relative permeability effect related to the residual oil in the simulation model, a better pressure match is achieved for the upper part of the reservoir. The pressure match is notably improved in the water injectors (Fig. 14) and there is a very limited impact in the pressure match for the oil producers. The reservoir pressure in the lower part of the reservoir remains unchanged; this demonstrates the positive

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Pressure plots showing the quality of the pressure match for the water injectors before and after the implementation of the residual oil in the simulation model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure plots showing the quality of the pressure match for the water injectors before and after the implementation of the residual oil in the simulation model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The incorporation of the residual oil in the studied field has another positive impact. The simulation model without residual oil was experiencing an early water breakthrough and higher water cut than the history data collected through the field life. In the model with residual oil, this issue is solved: the baffle induced by this oil delays the timing of water breakthrough and reduces the water cut (Fig. 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Water cut plot showing the impact of the residual oil on the timing of water breakthrough and the match of the water cut.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water cut plot showing the impact of the residual oil on the timing of water breakthrough and the match of the water cut.
